discussion.content:
Answer is A
D is not correct, the key is there is not enough data, not packets, from Palo documentation: 
What is the unknown-tcp or unknown-udp that sometimes shows up in traffic logs? In terms of App-ID, these are connections where not enough data, or data that did not match any known applications's behavior, were transferred and App-ID was unable to identify a known application.

comments.content: I think D is insufficient data
Regardless of how many packets you receive, some applications are always in an unknown TCP state, this is by design.

discussion.content: D can also be correct

Selected Answer: A
unknown-tcp:

Unknown-tcp means the firewall captured the three-way TCP handshake, but the application was not identified. This may be due to the use of a custom application for which the firewall does not have signatures

Selected Answer: A
A
TAKUM1y and mysteryzjoker provide correct explanation

Selected Answer: A
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClibCAC#:~:text=unknown%2Dtcp%3A,firewall%20does%20not%20have%20signatures.

Selected Answer: A
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClibCAC#:~:text=unknown%2Dtcp%3A,firewall%20does%20not%20have%20signatures.

questions.question_text:
While analyzing the Traffic log, you see that some entries show "unknown-tcp" in the Application column.
What best explains these occurrences?

choices.B: A handshake took place, but no data packets were sent prior to the timeout.
choices.C: A handshake did not take place, and the application could not be identified.
choices.A: A handshake did take place, but the application could not be identified.
choices.D: A handshake took place; however, there were not enough packets to identify the application.

questions.question_text:
You have upgraded Panorama to 10.2 and need to upgrade six Log Collectors.
When upgrading Log Collectors to 10.2, you must do what?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
You must upgrade all Log Collectors in a collector group at the same time to avoid losing log data

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-upgrade/upgrade-panorama/deploy-updates-to-firewalls-log-collectors-and-wildfire-appliances-using-panorama/deploy-an-update-to-log-collectors-when-panorama-is-internet-connected

Selected Answer: A
There is no mention of a log collector group, you should upgrade them one at a time.
I think it is A, there is no mention of a log collector group in the question. You upgrade log collectors one at a time and verify each upgrade is good before moving to the next one.

C - Upgrade all Log Collectors in a collector group at the same time to avoid losing log data

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-upgrade/upgrade-panorama/deploy-updates-to-firewalls-log-collectors-and-wildfire-appliances-using-panorama/deploy-an-update-to-log-collectors-when-panorama-is-internet-connected

Selected Answer: C
C
millosz222 and TAKUM1y are correct

Selected Answer: C
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-upgrade/upgrade-panorama/deploy-updates-to-firewalls-log-collectors-and-wildfire-appliances-using-panorama/deploy-an-update-to-log-collectors-when-panorama-is-internet-connected

choices.C: Upgrade all the Log Collectors at the same time.
choices.B: Add Panorama Administrators to each Managed Collector.
choices.D: Add a Global Authentication Profile to each Managed Collector.
choices.A: Upgrade the Log Collectors one at a time.

questions.question_text:
A firewall administrator has been tasked with ensuring that all Panorama-managed firewalls forward traffic logs to Panorama.
In which section is this configured?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I think in this is the A. Just checked in my lab, after configuring a template in Device - Log Settings.

Selected Answer: B
Create a Log Forwarding profile.
The profile defines the destinations for Traffic, Threat, WildFire Submission, URL Filtering, Data Filtering, Tunnel and Authentication logs.
Select Objects > Log Forwarding, select the Device Group of the firewalls that will forward logs, and Add a profile.

Option B

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/panorama/10-2/panorama-admin/manage-log-collection/configure-log-forwarding-to-panorama

Selected Answer: B
B
A is for system logs (System/Config/User-ID/HIP/GlobalProtect/Correlation), C&D have nothing to do with log forwarding
The answer is B. I dealt with this SO MUCH at my last job!

Selected Answer: B
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClcICAS
none of the answers are relevant to the question.

Selected Answer: B
B
commit will fail

its B, it fails the commit should the local FW has the same object as the Panorama.
on this docs it say "shared"
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/panorama/9-1/panorama-admin/manage-firewalls/transition-a-firewall-to-panorama-management/plan-the-transition-to-panorama-management
It's B. A is wrong as that is discussing the IMPORT into PAN; not the export push down. The Commit will fail with an error displaying the duplicate object.

It's B, just tested on lab

Validation Error:
. address -> Test duplicate 'Test duplicate' is already in use

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/panorama/9-1/panorama-admin/manage-firewalls/transition-a-firewall-to-panorama-management/plan-the-transition-to-panorama-management
A - If a shared firewall object has the same name and value as an existing shared Panorama object, the import excludes that firewall object.

questions.question_text:
An engineer is pushing configuration from Panorama to a managed firewall.
What happens when the pushed Panorama configuration has Address Object names that duplicate the Address Objects already configured on the firewall?

choices.C: The firewall fully commits all of the pushed configuration and overwrites its locally configured objects.
choices.A: The firewall ignores only the pushed objects that have the same name as the locally configured objects, and it will commit the rest of the pushed configuration.
choices.D: The firewall renames the duplicate local objects with "-1" at the end signifying they are clones; it will update the references to the objects accordingly and fully commit the pushed configuration.
choices.B: The firewall rejects the pushed configuration, and the commit fails.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correct answer is A

Selected Answer: A
voting comment for option A
Option A is correct.
Typical malicious PANW test question using obscure terms. What does the word "Profile" have to do with anything here? The answer is "Admin Role"...
Option A is correct.
a is the correct answer because it depends of the admin role assigned
Answer: A

Which profile is the cause of the missing Policies tab?
